A diagonal matrix D = [dij] in M44(R) has integer entries and |D| = 12. Find all possible values of d22 and d44 if d11 = 3 and d33 = 1. Solution: Every diagonal matrix D ∈ M44(R) satisﬁes |D| = d11d22d33d44. Since for these diagonal matrix in question, 12 = d11d22d33d44 = 3d22d44 ⇐⇒ 4 = d22d44. Prove, using determinants, that A·B is invertible iﬀ A and B are invertible. Solution: Recall that for A ∈ Mnn(R) we have A−1 exists iﬀ |A| ̸= 0, and, |A · B| = |A||B|. Therefore, (A · B) −1 exists ⇐⇒ |A · B| ̸= 0 ⇐⇒ |A||B| ̸= 0 ⇐⇒ |A| ̸= 0 and |B| ̸= 0. ⇐⇒ A −1 exists and B−1 exists, as required. ■ 4 1VGLA: DETERMINANTS PRACTICE QUESTIONS (A) Question 10. Let A and B be invertible matrices in Mnn(R). Determine the value of det(A · B · A−1 · B−1). Recall, matrix multiplication in Mnn(R) is not commutative. Solution: Recall that |A−1| = |A| −1. Then, we have |A · B · A−1 · B−1| = |A||B||A−1||B−1| = |A||B| 1 |A| 1 |B| = 1. A matrix A ∈ Mnn(R) is called an orthogonal matrix if A · AT = AT · A = In. List all elements of the set S = {x ∈ R : n ∈ N, A ∈ Mnn(R) is an orthogonal matrix and |A| = x} . Solution: For any orthogonal matrix A · AT = In =⇒ |A||AT | = |In| =⇒ |A| 2 = 1. Therefore, S ⊂ {−1, 1}. For n ∈ N, the matrix In is an orthogonal matrix with |In| = 1. (a)    −3x + 3y − 4z = 0 − 3y = 0 −3x + 2y − 4z = 0, (b)    5x − 4y − z = 0 −5x + 6y − z = 0 −4x + 9y − 5z = 0. Is it true of false that a homogeneous system of n linear equations, say, A · x = 0, has non-trivial solutions if and only if |A| = 0? 8 1VGLA: DETERMINANTS PRACTICE QUESTIONS Solution: It is false since not all linear systems of n equations are in n unknowns i.e. A does not necessarily have a determinant. To clarify, consider A ∈ M23(R) given by (1 0 0 0 1 0 ) , for which the induced linear system has non-trivial solutions but A does not have a determinant. ■ (B) Question 19. For σ ∈ Sn with N (σ) > 0, establish that there exists i ∈ Σn such that σ(i) > σ(i + 1). Solution: Suppose that there does not exist i ∈ Σn such that σ(i) > σ(i + 1). Then 1 ≤ σ(1) ≤ σ(2) ≤ σ(3) ≤ . . . ≤ σ(n − 1) ≤ σ(n) ≤ n. Since σ is a bijection from Σn to Σn it follows that σ(i) = i for i = 1, . . . , n and hence N (σ) = 0, which is a contradiction. Therefore, there exists i ∈ Σn such that σ(i) > σ(i + 1). ■ (B) Question 20. Solution: ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ 1 1 1 a b c a2 b2 c2 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ = ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ 1 0 0 a b − a c − a a2 b2 − a2 c2 − a2 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ( c2 → c2 − c1 c3 → c3 − c1 ) = 1.(−1)1+1 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ b − a c − a b2 − a2 c2 − a2 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ = (b − a)(c2 − a2) − (c − a)(b2 − a2) = (b − a)(c − a)(c + a) − (c − a)(b − a)(b + a) = (b − a)(c − a)(c + a − b − a) = (a − b)(b − c)(c − a) 10 1VGLA: DETERMINANTS PRACTICE QUESTIONS ■ (B) Question 23. Therefore |A − λI3| = 0 ⇐⇒ λ ∈ {1, 2, 3}. (b) |A − λI3| = ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ 1 − λ 2 −3 0 −4 − λ 0 7 8 9 − λ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ = −(λ + 4)(−1)2+2 ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ 1 − λ −3 7 9 − λ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ ∣ = −(λ + 4)((1 − λ)(9 − λ) + 21) = −(λ + 4)(λ2 − 10λ + 30).
